bibl.title: Letter from John H. Andrus to John J. Moran, March 2, 1938

div1.p: Andrus thanks Moran for the introduction to Hench and is curious about Hench's interest. He relates family news.

div1.head: Letter from John H. Andrus to John J. Moran, March 2, 1938
div1.opener:
J.H. Andrus
805 Cooper St.
Camden, N. J.
3-2-38.
Mr. John J. Moran,
Avenida Menocal 102-A
Havana, Cuba.
Dear Friend Moran:
div1.p:
It was mighty nice of you to write me about Doctor Hench and
I want you to know that I appreciate it.

Since you have gone to so much trouble, I am enclosing copies
of my son's letter, my letter and “Layman's Case History”, all
going to Doctor Hench today.

I am wondering WHY Dr. Hench is interesting himself in my case.
Do you know? Did you suggest that he do so? Is he look-
ing into spinal trouble as an after-math of yellow fever?

No matter what the reason, I am grateful but have not the remo-
test hope that he will be able to do anything for me.

There is nothing new to write about since I wrote you last.
Am still “enjoying” my neuritic pains and headache but, despite
all that, still get more fun out of life than you would imagine.

Did I tell you that I have a grandson - now six months OLD -
in perfect health and full of the old Nick. He and I have
a session every day. From this you know that I have join-
ed that fraternity of old fossils, each of whom is the grand-
parent of the most wonderful grandchild that ever lived.

Have been writing some cigar copy for E. R. Montero Havana Co.
They have a stripping plant in Pinar del Rio and a warehouse
in Havana. Mr. Montero has just returned from Cuba and
tells me that business there is very good. Hope this will
mean more and easier dinero for my friend Moran.
Write when you can. I enjoy your letters very much.
In the meantime, kindest regards and best wishes.
